results.title: Churchill: champion of freedom
results.creator_credit: George Grafton Green and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: Follows the life of Churchill from his entry into politics, his part in World War I, his early prediction of World War II and his defiant unconquerable leadership of his government, Britain, and the free world against Hitler. He saw his statue unveiled in Guild Hall, became Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports; and was revered by all on his 80th birthday - he became a legend in his lifetime. Includes 1911 film footage of Churchill as Home Secretary at the siege of Sydney Street, London’s East End. Commentary by Wynford Vaughan-Thomas.

results.title: Churchill
results.creator_credit: Marisa Appugliese, Jeremy Bennett, ABC-TV (Australia), Arts and Entertainment Network and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: This magnificent four hour video explores the man behind the war image. With original archive footage of his home life, his extensive political campaigns and of the battles of two world wars, this outstanding film offers a vivid portrait of arguably the greatest statesman Britain has ever known.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marisa Appugliese, Jeremy Bennett, ABC-TV (Australia), Arts and Entertainment Network and BBC-TV

results.title: Chungking express
results.creator_credit: Wong, Chan Yi-Kan and Jet Tone Production
results.brief_description: Director Wong Kar-Wai, working again with cinematographer Christopher Doyle brings together two loosely connected stories of unrequited love, drug smuggling, fast-food joints and melancholic cops. Revisiting his regular themes of chance vs fate and broken hearted loners, Wong Kar-Wai and Doyle (sharing his DOP duties with Lau Wai-Keung), again have created a heightened world of neon drenched cities and smokey bars, while the soundtrack repeats it’s ethereal refrain of the Mamas and the Papas California dreaming. The first story centers around the infamous Chungking mansions as a lovelorn cop, identified as No.223 (Takeshi Kaneshiro) yearns over a mysterious woman (Brigitte Lin) in dark sunglasses and a Marilyn Monroe style wig. Unbeknownst to the sombre detective, who has a peculiar nostalgic attachment to crushed canned pineapple, the woman is working on the other side of the law as a small time heroin smuggler. The second randomly linked story is set around the Midnight Express fast-food joint where cop No.663 (Tony Leung) spends most of his nights, recovering over a break up with an air hostess (Valerie Chow), unaware that the young woman who works behind the counter (Hong Kong rock star Faye Wong) is quietly infatuated with him. In Cantonese and Mandarin with English subtitles.

constellations_other.name: Wong Kar-Wai's Hollywood fingerprints
constellations_other.description: Wong Kar-wai’s modern masterpiece In The Mood For Love is a rich, romantic melodrama that follows the entangled lives of two neighbours (Tony Leung and Maggie Cheung) who develop feelings for each other after learning their spouses are having an affair.

results.title: Chuckwagon
results.creator_credit: Robert Barclay, Chetwynd Films and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Produced in 1964, this film is a ringside view of the chuckwagon race, star attraction of the world-famous Calgary stampede. Once ponderous Percherons and Clydesdales thundered around the course. Now they are racers, and it takes a firm hand to guide such horsepower. “Chuckwagon” brings to the screen an exciting account of this extraordinary event. (Award: Cragnasco)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Barclay, Chetwynd Films and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Chuck & Buck
results.creator_credit: Miguel Arteta, Matthew Greenfield and Flan de Coco Film
results.brief_description: Chuck (Chris Weitz) and Buck (Mike White) were best friends as boys, but with the passing of time, Chuck has ended up a successful record executive in Los Angeles, while Buck has remained at home looking after his invalid mother. When the two of them meet at Buck’s mother’s funeral, Buck decides to follow his old friend to LA. But Chuck, now engaged and a professional, has little time for the nostalgic games that Buck wants to play. In order to win his old friend back, Buck stages a play at the theatre across the road from Chuck’s work. But the play - honest and fantastical, an adult fairytale - has far from the desired effect. Miguel Arteta’s film begins as an initially finely comic study of Buck, an innocent, unworldy man trapped in the fantasies of childhood. But increasingly, as his stalking of Chuck becomes obsessive and malignant, a darker tone appears in this film. Childhood games are revealed to be far from innocent: Buck wants to return to the playfulness of their sexual exploration when they were adolescent boys; but Chuck is fearful of the unresolved tensions and consequences of this early experimentation. Both Buck’s relentless refusal to be an adult, and Chuck’s equally fervent denial of his childhood sexuality lead to potentially dangerous consequences for both themselves and those around them. “Chuck and Buck” suggests it is only through the translating of his obsessions and fears into theatre, into drama and art, that Buck can find a way to release himself from the legacy of his childhood. For all its menace, “Chuck and Buck” allows the possibility not only for tolerance but an understanding to emerge between the old friends; an understanding not predicated on either false nostalgia or on denying the eroticism of friendship. The film also features some light-hearted affectionate satire about actors, auditions and the theatre world and features an excellent support performance by Lupe Ontiveros. Paul Weitz plays Chuck’s theatrical alter-ego. The film was shot on digital video format.

results.title: Chronopolis
results.brief_description:
Chronopolis is a city lost in space. The inhabitants are immortal and they attempt to relieve their boredom by manufacturing time. They are all awaiting a liberating cataclysm which will break the monotony of their endless lives. During one of their manufactured moments, the Chronossians meet a human being in the person of a mountaineer.

Credits: Producer, Marcelle Ponti ; director, Piotr Kamler ; writer, Piotr Kamler, Gabrielle Althen ; photography, Piotr Kamler ; music, Luc Ferrari.
Cast: Michel Lonsdale [narration].

results.title: Chronicle of a love = Loving lie
results.brief_description: Antonioni’s highly acclaimed first film relates the tale of an adulterous wife and her impoverished lover who plan to murder her rich husband. He dies before they carry out the deed and they have to live with the guilt of their intentions. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Chronicle of a disappearance [NTSC]
results.brief_description: Formally daring within its rigorous and restrained aesthetic, Palestinian director Elia Suleiman’s episodic, elliptical cinematic essay about what it meant to be a Palestinian in the Occupied Territories in 1996, is constructed in two parts. “Nazareth, A Personal Diary”, set in Suleiman’s birthplace, renders a series of vignettes of everyday life with its rounds of boredom, solitude, complaint, conviviality, and often surreal contradiction. Characters wander in and out of the film, essentially writing their own diary entries. Part two “Jerusalem, A Political Diary” features Suleiman himself as a deadpan internal exile observing events around him: rampant, chaotic tourism in the Holy Land, and the terrors of partition and paranoia which culminate in a personal encounter with the Israeli army during a house raid which is both scary and absurd. According to Suleiman, the film depicts ‘a situation of stasis, characterised by deprivation, disillusionment, and lack of action’. Angry, sad, witty and tender, the film does not provide distinct answers to questions of Palestinian identity. Rather it offers an assortment of possible truths as it explores, through Suleiman’s own eyes, the effects of ghettoisation and marginalisation on the Palestinian psyche. The film won the Best First Feature Award at Venice Film Festival in 1996. In Arabic with English subtitles.
